;;在我们的冬季文化预览中，;我们的评论家们总结了排得满满的日历上最激动人心的活动。奥斯卡季——拉开了帷幕今年夏天，两部主导文化的大片比平常更早上映，正如火如荼地进行中，其中包括布莱德利·库珀的《大师》，一部以伦纳德·伯恩斯坦的爱情生活为中心的传记片；艾娃·杜威奈的《起源》，讲述了他的爱情生活。记者;伊莎贝尔·威尔克森;撰写开创性书籍的路径“;种姓：我们不满的根源;”；埃默拉尔德·芬内尔（Emerald Fennell）的滑稽的离水鱼奇幻作品“Saltburn”；欧格斯·兰斯莫斯 (Yorgos Lanthimos) 的《可怜的东西》(Poor Things) 中，艾玛·斯通 (Emma Stone) 饰演一名被诡计多端的科学家复活的女人。在剧院，我们期待;迈克尔·R·杰克逊;和安娜·K·雅各布斯根据怪异恐怖的阴道牙齿电影《牙齿》改编的音乐剧。圣安仓库上演“生活与生活” 《迈克尔·K 时代》，改编自《战马》的 Handspring 木偶，摘自 ;JM Coetzee; 1983 年的小说，讲述南非种族隔离引发的内战。寻求一阵喜悦？萨顿·福斯特 (Sutton Foster) 出现在《床垫童话》中，为“安可！”几周后，她将前往百老汇，在《;《理发师陶德》;》，二月份与亚伦·特维特演对手戏，取代乔什·格罗班担任主角。 （还有时间欣赏优秀的原创演员阵容。）麦当娜在巴克莱银行和麦迪逊广场花园举办了庆祝巡演（演出名单似乎是史诗般的），玛丽亚·凯莉也以只有玛丽亚才能做到的方式在节日中响起，也在 MSG 然后Sleater-Kinney 的 ;Mitski; 让寒冷的月份变得温暖起来和布列塔尼·霍华德（阿拉巴马奶昔乐队）。艺术亮点包括大都会博物馆对哈莱姆文艺复兴时期的庞大调查和;MOMA;的琼·乔纳斯回顾展。在舞蹈方面，菲利普·格拉斯的钢琴练习曲给众多舞蹈家带来了灵感，皮娜·鲍什不可磨灭的《春之祭》则由塞内加尔编舞家热尔曼·阿科尼 (Germaine Acogny) 的 École des Sables 表演。新年前夜，大都会歌剧院推出了新的《卡门》，布林·特菲尔、丹尼尔·特里福诺夫和维金古尔·奥拉夫森在卡内基音乐厅的演出季中星光熠熠。我们在那里见。

;
;杂志、哈莱姆文艺复兴、琼·乔纳斯
;

;美国民间艺术博物馆没有得到足够的喜爱，因此其大型冬季展览以忽视为主题是很合适的。 ;“无名人物：早期美国北部黑人的存在与缺席”;（11 月 15 日开幕）标榜自己是对早期美国种族主义是“主要是南方问题”的观念的“纠正”，但这个描述似乎过于谦虚了。大约 125 件创作于 17 世纪末至 19 世纪初的作品，为梅森-迪克森线以上的黑人生活提供了充满活力、有时甚至是悲剧性的景象。

;

;11 月下旬，布鲁克林博物馆给了另一个被忽视的主题一些迟来的关注。 ;“复印机宣言：制作杂志的艺术家”;（11 月 17 日）是北美首个探索同人杂志的大型展览，同人杂志是近几十年来较为折衷的媒体形式之一。近千件艺术作品带我们游览了朋克、酷儿和嘻哈亚文化，所有这些都陶醉于该杂志的多功能性。这里展出的一些著名艺术家，如卡罗琳·施尼曼 (Carolee Schneemann)，因其其他创作而闻名，但大多数艺术家却鲜为人知。迟到总比不到好。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;< p >;;玛伦·哈辛格 (Maren Hassinger); 今年已经七十六岁了，她在媒体领域创作了一些最具影响力的作品，这些作品非常非正统，以至于杂志看起来像水彩画。 1983年，她将一束束铁缆安装在水泥底座上，并将看起来有点像一团麦秆的结果称为“田野”。正如标题所暗示的那样，哈辛格的艺术一只脚踏入自然世界，另一只脚踏入工业。该雕塑在 Dia Beacon 的展出（12 月 16 日）标志着它在中断三十多年后再次回到公众视野。

;
;;

;哈罗德·科恩 (Harold Cohen) 是加州大学圣地亚哥分校的一名画家和讲师，他在 1968 年至 2016 年科恩去世期间创作了 AARON 的多个版本，这是最早能够进行艺术创作的人工智能软件程序之一。惠特尼博物馆展出的作品包括彩色和黑白的图画和绘画，有些是具象的，有些是抽象的。 （将会有艾伦的艺术过程的现场演示。）人们不禁想知道，如果它的发明者活得更久的话，这个程序将会做什么样的工作——而且，按照事情的进展，是否会有有知觉的机器人，渴望向他们杰出的祖先致敬，当;“哈罗德·科恩：亚伦”;（2 月 3 日）欢迎顾客进门时。

;

;哈莱姆文艺复兴一个世纪过去了，文化历史学家仍然不确定如何处理它。大都会艺术博物馆雄心勃勃的调查——自八十年代以来纽约市艺术博物馆的首次调查——将这一运动视为现代主义的一种形式：区域性和国际性，与大迁徙和吉姆·克劳法联系在一起，也与埃及美学和欧洲美学相关。前卫。 ;“哈莱姆文艺复兴与跨大西洋现代主义”;（2 月 25 日）展出了大约一百六十件摄影、雕塑、电影和绘画作品，其中一些来自博物馆的永久收藏，另一些则是从历史博物馆借来的黑人学院和大学。

;

;现年八十七岁的琼·乔纳斯 (Joan Jonas) 的艺术拒绝分类，但;MOMA;正在尝试。回顾展;“琼·乔纳斯：晚安早安”;（3 月 17 日）是视频、电影、雕塑、摄影、绘画和舞蹈的丰盛融合，通常涉及性别、表演和生态等主题。乔纳斯对民间传说有着浓厚的兴趣，装置作品“杜松树”就证明了这一点；她最近的一些作品融入了受海洋生物学研究启发的想法，营造出一种既科学又神秘的氛围。—;;Jackson Arn ;;

;

;艾丽西亚·凯斯 (Alicia Keys)，“牙齿”，弹球向导
;

;在今年秋天庄严的节目节奏之后，随着夜晚越来越长，剧院将全面投入运营。它以一系列传记音乐剧开始，包括由艾丽西亚·凯斯（Alicia Keys）以某种隐晦的方式创作的;“地狱厨房”;（公共剧院；11 月 19 日开始预演）； ;《阿农西亚花园》;（维维安·博蒙特；11 月 20 日），由迈克尔·约翰·拉基乌萨 (Michael John LaChiusa) 撰写，讲述导演兼编舞格雷西拉·丹尼尔 (Graciela Daniele) 的故事；和;“布埃纳维斯塔社交俱乐部”;（大西洋剧院公司；11 月 17 日），马可·拉米雷斯将古巴乐队同名专辑的创作戏剧化，打造出一部充满音乐的作品。

;<感恩节前后，恰逢令人不舒服的晚餐谈话，莎拉·保尔森 (Sarah Paulson) 出现在布兰登·雅各布斯·詹金斯 (Branden Jacobs-Jenkins) 的百老汇首演家庭剧《适当》（Hayes；11 月 28 日）中，其中白人继承人发现他们宝贵的——但在道德上令人反感的——遗产。以它的方式，;“生活与生活” 《Times of Michael K》（圣安仓库；11 月 29 日）是一部广为巡演的以木偶为中心的改编作品，改编自 JM 库切 1983 年的小说，以南非为背景，讲述了一个类似的故事，讲述了种族主义在几代人中缓慢蔓延的故事.

;
;
;

;在百老汇，寒冷的天气需要清醒的节目安排：曼哈顿剧院俱乐部演奏约书亚·哈蒙 (Joshua Harmon) 的;“为法兰西共和国祈祷”;（Samuel J.弗里德曼（Friedman）；12月19日）到百老汇，在那里它关于以色列承诺的争论将特别深刻；凯莉·奥哈拉 (Kelli O'Hara) 和布莱恩·达西·詹姆斯 (Brian d'Arcy James) 主演了;《葡萄酒与玫瑰的日子》;（Studio 54；1 月 6 日），克雷格·卢卡斯 (Craig Lucas) 和亚当·古特尔 (Adam Guettel) 改编自这部有关酗酒的电影的音乐剧；泰恩·戴利 (Tyne Daly) 和列维·施赖伯 (Liev Schreiber) 出演约翰·帕特里克·尚利 (John Patrick Shanley) 2004 年的戏剧《怀疑》(Doubt)（美国航空；2 月 2 日）的翻拍版，该剧讲述了一名不信任牧师的修女的故事。

;;
;
;

;

;不过，距百老汇一英寸，剧院正在紧锣密鼓地进行。 “安可！”在纽约市中心的复兴计划中，充满活力的萨顿·福斯特 (Sutton Foster) 出演了玛丽·罗杰斯 (Mary Rodgers) 深受喜爱的;“床垫往事”;（1 月 24 日至 28 日），而比利·波特 (Billy Porter) 则出演了;“果冻” Last Jam”（2 月 21 日至 25 日），乔治·C·沃尔夫 (George C. Wolfe) 对果冻·罗尔·莫顿 (Jelly Roll Morton) 的寓言式致敬。令人眼花缭乱的实验戏剧节;Under the Radar;（1 月 5 日至 21 日）将其前卫的国际剧目散布在整个城市；同样大胆（但更节俭）的;指数音乐节;主要在布鲁克林举办，整个一月份都有一系列奇怪且令人大开眼界的节目。

;

;百老汇外的音乐节真正大展身手随着岁月的流逝。标志剧院经历了一次衰落，但最终凭借多米尼克·莫里索的;“日落宝贝”;（1 月 30 日）回归，该剧讲述了一位黑人革命政治犯和他关系疏远的女儿的故事。 2023 年我最喜欢的两部节目正在加演：Shayok Misha Chowdhury 的英语和孟加拉语双语杰作;“公共猥亵行为”;（波隆斯基莎士比亚中心；1 月 17 日）和 Joey Merlo 的;“与 Theda Bara 一起在片场”（《Brick》；2 月 1 日），这是一部由大卫·格林斯潘 (David Greenspan) 表演的怪异降神剧，他引导了众多观众。而且，说到混乱，《奇怪的循环》的杰出作曲家迈克尔·R·杰克逊与安娜·K·雅各布斯一起创作了一部改编自阴道牙齿电影《牙齿》的音乐剧（剧作家地平线；二月下旬），这应该会成为本季的一大亮点。

;
;
;

;然后就差不多了春天，百老汇音乐剧盛行，包括《大象之水》（Imperial；2 月 24 日），这是根据萨拉·格鲁恩 (Sara Gruen) 的小说改编的，由欢乐、平易近人的 PigPen 乐团演出；英格丽德·迈克尔森 (Ingrid Michaelson) 和贝卡·布伦斯特 (Bekah Brunstetter) 改编的;《恋恋笔记本》;（Schoenfeld；3 月 14 日）；和;“谁是汤米”;（在 Nederlander 玩弹球；3 月 8 日）。最后，从三月的某一天（具体日期尚未确定）开始，杰里米·斯特朗出现在百老汇的;“人民公敌”;中，这是艾米·赫尔佐格根据亨利克·易卜生关于难以忽视的真相的警世故事改编的版本。这个角色会赢得斯特朗和托尼奖吗？人们只能假设《继承之战》的长子会知道如何争夺王冠。-;;海伦肖;;

;当代音乐

;;
;
;;
;
;伯爵运动衫、Cat Power、麦当娜
;

;关于音乐流派有两种截然不同的思路：一些艺术家将自己视为颠覆者，另一些艺术家则将自己视为原型。这种二元关系在冬季音乐会季节上演，由处于职业生涯不同阶段的艺术家主导，其中既有寻求扩大声音的勘察家，也有已进入不同领域的先驱者。这两种方法都可以（而且确实）有助于激发现场表演的活力。

;

;一些说唱工匠展示了他们的灵巧。在布鲁克林钢铁公司，这位从学者变成圣人的 ;Earl Sweatshirt; 与他的长期合作者、地下节奏制作人 ;the Alchemist;（11 月 22 日）以及好奇的前诗人 ; 建立了联系>;Noname;（11 月 27 日）继续对她最近的专辑“Sundial”进行元嘻哈评论。 1 月 26 日，芝加哥同胞 ;Mick Jenkins; 用他自己的铿锵有力的文字游戏击中了 Racket，探索个人成长和动力。

;对于那些寻找更有冲击力的东西的人来说，有一些摇滚乐手正在制作沉重的音乐，非常漂亮，可以作为电源弹出进行扫描。 11 月 17 日，在欧文广场，朋克摇滚乐队 ;the Armed; 用电子乐演绎了后硬核歌曲。韦伯斯特音乐厅举办了两场不同强度的演出：金属乐队 ;Baroness; 与即兴硬摇滚乐队 ;Sheer Mag;（11 月 29 日）和独立明星 ; Sky Ferreira（12 月 11 日），其 2013 年唯一一张专辑《Night Time, My Time》至今仍是摇滚乐界的里程碑。

;

;独立摇滚偶像凭借新专辑继续前进音乐，深入研究他们的唱片，或者挖掘其他杰出人物的遗产。 11 月 24 日，在国王剧院，开创性的创作型歌手 ;Liz Phair; 结束了长达十年的录音中断，于 2021 年携专辑《Soberish》回归，释放了清醒的分离音乐。 2 月 14 日，;Cat Power; 在卡内基音乐厅演唱了伟大的鲍勃·迪伦 (Bob Dylan) 的歌曲。 ;帕蒂·史密斯; ;和她的乐队;返回布鲁克林钢铁公司进行两场演出（12 月 29 日至 30 日），同一场地迎来了骚乱 grrrls ;Sleater-Kinney; strong>;（3 月 13 日至 14 日），首次推出该乐队即将发行的专辑“Little Rope”中的音乐。

;

;所有活着的人都有三个共同点：身体，最终死亡的确定性，以及曾经有人日以继夜地努力照顾你的事实。在你生命之初，有人关心——这里用来描述一种行为，而不是一种感觉——足以维持这种活力。我们每个人都是一座纪念碑，一座纪念馆，纪念着我们所付出的巨大劳动，这些劳动完全是为了我们而完成的，但我们已经不再记得了。套用儿童心理分析师 DW Winnicott 的话：给我一个婴儿，我就会给你看附近的人。

;

;凯特·布里格斯 (Kate Briggs) 的首部小说，“;长形式;”是这种亲密关系的写照，是“至少两个人的社区”的写照。情节看似简单：海伦和她的孩子罗丝一起度过了一天。到目前为止，他们已经度过了近六周的日子，在持续、密切的亲密关系中度过。但对于“一天”的定义已经消失，社会共识的粘合剂也随之消失，露出了之前隐藏的原始时间的光芒。这在一定程度上是由于睡眠不足——有一次，海伦在看到一条河流流淌时哭泣，她的疲倦决定了她——而且还因为这就是一个非常年幼的婴儿的存在所做的事情。它迫使你抬起并观察几分钟，就像它们是大石头，笨重的连续性块，下面困着潮湿的、蜿蜒的生命。如果做得好，这也是小说可以做到的。

;

;早上，一本书到达海伦的家门口：“;《弃婴汤姆·琼斯的历史》;，亨利·菲尔丁 (Henry Fielding) 着，最初出版于 1749 年。这本巨著（我的副本有九百七十五页）陪伴海伦和罗丝度过了他们的一天。哭泣、蹦蹦跳跳、公园散步、大量的观察、思考、一些惊慌、打瞌睡，以及喝了几杯茶。 《汤姆·琼斯》被放下又被捡起，一个世界进入又离开，就像另一种婴儿一样，没有致命的风险。布里格斯将这两项活动交织在一起，增加了标准化时间的重量——小说阅读和婴儿护理。 “长篇”在散文间奏中理论化了阅读和护理，带着一种缓慢的严肃和一种狡猾的奇迹，符合所描述的作品的利害关系：“参与一个可能的;你<的启动是什么？ /em>;。”

;

;布里格斯以其作为翻译家的反思和富有洞察力的工作而闻名，特别是她对理论家罗兰·巴特晚期讲座的翻译，收集为“;如何共同生活;”和“;小说的准备;”，从法语翻译成英语。她关于翻译的精彩长篇论文“;This Little Art;”，发表于 2017 年，可以追溯到这一点早期的作品、她的选择和过程，同时也允许怀疑、批判性感叹、个人经验和观点、风格的多样性——传统上译者希望把所有这些都放在一边，以更好地体现语言之间更直接的联系。 《长篇》延续了布里格斯与巴特（另一个“至少两个人的共同体”）的学术亲密关系。标题是她对他的短语的翻译，用于“小说的准备”，用于描述小说本身。

;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;

;在这些讲义中，包括他意外去世前的一些讲义，巴特着迷于想要写一部小说和人们可以如何去做，特别是如何从撰写观察或传记片段（“短形式”）转变为更具叙事性和广泛性的“长形式”。我们都知道，当遇到一本完全身临其境的书时，就像暴风雨过后凌乱的玫瑰丛一样，那种闪耀而令人刺痛的敬畏时刻——“他们是怎么做到的？”我们问，伸手但不触碰。布里格斯的《长篇》是从这些调查的基础上发出的亮绿色芽，以小说本身的形式萌芽出进一步的问题。如何写一篇较长的文本的问题变成了如何继续超越你已经知道的内容，这变成了如何继续下去，忍受过于简短的无休止的延伸，这又回到了另一个提出的问题巴特所著，布里格斯翻译：“如何生活在一起？”

;
;
;

;对于布里格斯来说，这个智力螺旋的中心是一个婴儿。婴儿和她的母亲，因为婴儿永远不会被单独发现。她永远是一个标志：盲曲线！前面的关系！在小说中，海伦对“母性”这个词感到愤怒，因为它只强调了这个二人充满活力、令人发狂的共同生活中的单身成年参与者。 “这让它听起来像是一种稳定，也是一种封闭。当她将其体验为面对（向外）时：面对并面对这个实际的另一个身体，同样存在，她的问题贯穿她，有时，她感受到了她的想法。”

;布里格斯经常使用“项目”、“情况”、“构图”或“实践”等词来描述海伦正在做的工作——“一项不受支持的发明，前所未有的联合制作”。这种语言唤起了海伦为促进罗斯的舒适和兴趣而进行的空间安排，例如放置多纹理的垫子，以一定角度放置在悬挂式手机的呼吸形状下方。这些设置不断被开创、拆除和重新构思——昨天有效的方法今天可能行不通，一小时前有效的方法今天可能行不通。在《如何共同生活》中，巴特将所有小说描述为围绕“模型”（建筑师按比例缩小的空间模型）构建的模拟。想象“模型”的另一种方式可以是玩偶之家，甚至是婴儿床。一个没有第四堵墙的小结构，充满了柔软的近乎个性的人，热切地等待着他们所承诺的叙述。

;

;布里格斯突出了照顾新生儿的即兴创作品质，以及海伦“情境”中固有的永恒创造力，总是注定无常。与此同时，海伦必须面对这样一个事实：她觉得极其原创的东西最多被认为是普通的、自然的、甚至是死记硬背的。 （当然，在最坏的情况下，养育的工作被认为是愚蠢的动物性、智力上的乏味和身体上的怪诞。）这些是“一套对她来说是新鲜的古老姿势”，不断地被撤销和重做。在照顾婴儿的过程中，轮子每天都会被重新发明，这听起来像是西西弗斯式的，但也很强烈、神奇：如果你每天都能震惊地意识到以前闻所未闻的轮子的可能性会怎样？罗丝不知道轮子是什么，海伦也不知道。 Both are concurrently discovering their day's technologies, their ways of getting around, their shapes and systems. Much of the time, what each uncovers is the shadowy crooks and swells of the other. Rose exhales the unworldly wail of the very young, Helen lies down with Rose at her breast. Briggs writes, “The two of them, calling out their present-ness to each other, re-affirming it, calming with it, sometimes oppressing with it, and in doing so fraying a path for themselves and for their togetherness in the already said.”

;

;Helen tries to keep track of the information that she and Rose seem to be accumulating, to chart wakings, feedings, moods—“a succession of rolling, ragged-edged atmospheric states.” But nothing coheres “because there was no subordination: one phase didn't seem to matter any more or less than any other.” This is life “a-patterned.” Rose challenges and expands the structure of “morning” or “afternoon” by way of decimating the concept of “night,” previously known as a thing one sleeps through. At first, it might sound like Briggs is trying to question the basics of plot or suspense, but, in fact, “The Long Form” is gripping, with all the satisfactions of more traditional narratives, albeit in unprecedented places. When the fictional doorbell rang after pages and pages of Helen trying to put Rose down, trying to gently drift her into a very necessary morning nap, I almost yelped out “No!” like an action hero sprinting toward a preventable explosion, pathetic hand outstretched—we had worked so hard, and now it was over!

;“What is it like?” Helen's friend Rebba asks. To have a baby, she means, “living alongside a beginner,” as Briggs puts it elsewhere. Helen spreads her hands apart, languageless. She would need to invent a new way of using her words to fully answer her friend's question. “It would take longer,” longer than anything she had been tasked with communicating before. Perhaps this is why—putting the behemoth of misogyny aside for a moment—the novel, as a form and a category, has generally failed to delve into this very popular, very extraordinary part of life. Motherhood requires a stretching of preconceived time, maybe even a smashing of it. Briggs writes, “This is what length (continuance; life) is made from (falling in and falling out). It is what staying-with (a question; a theme; a live, vulnerable creature) over time actually involves: starting and stopping, beginning again, likely from somewhere else, on a new basis, because the whole thing has not yet ended and it is important that it should carry on.” Ironically, the novel is perfectly suited for representing the reality of care work—deeply durational yet chaptered, a dense weave of fragments, spanning thick minutes and thin minutes, open-facing as all metaphor must be. An activity that constitutes a shelter. “The Long Form” suggests that we are all part of the relative beginning of this form. Reading Briggs, I felt the novel, as a genre, lift its head and look around the room, with all the effort, focus, and luminous curiosity of a newborn, seeing in a way it hadn't seen before. ♦

;The new film from Sofia Coppola, “Priscilla,” begins in 1959. Sitting at the counter of a diner at a US Army base in Germany, Priscilla Beaulieu (Cailee Spaeny) is asked whether she likes Elvis Presley. She answers with a question: “Of course, who doesn't?” Priscilla is petite, polite, and fourteen—a little older than Juliet was when she first bumped into Romeo. The exciting, if alarming, news is that Elvis, the most unattainable of stars, has swung into her orbit. He's currently stationed nearby, serving in the military, and Priscilla is invited to meet him at a party. Romeo is right there in the room. “You're just a baby,” Elvis tells her. “Thanks,” she replies.

;

;Elvis is played by Jacob Elordi, who, by my estimate, is about three times taller than his co-star. As a result, the rapport between Elvis and Priscilla appears to be powered less by loving hearts than by simple hydraulics; he has to lean over and down as if hinged, like an industrial crane, for a word in her ear. (Later in the movie, she acquires a towering beehive, but that doesn't really solve the problem. “Talk to the hair” is not something you say to Elvis Presley.) Nonetheless, the two of them fuse, sharing pangs of homesickness, and it's not long before Elvis is introduced to Priscilla's mother, Ann (Dagmara Dominczyk), and stepfather, Paul (Ari Cohen). “I happen to be very fond of your daughter,” Elvis reassures them. When he takes her out for the evening, Paul—a captain, and therefore Elvis's superior in rank—commands him to “bring her home by 2200.” This is the Army, son.

;

;The rest of the movie charts the rise and fall of a strange romance, as viewed through Priscilla's eyes. We stay with her as Elvis, his soldierly duties complete, heads home. “How's my little one?” he asks, in a long-distance phone call. Armed with a first-class ticket on Pan Am—and, for some unfathomable reason, the consent of her parents—Priscilla goes to visit him, arriving at Graceland in a pink dress and white gloves. After a bacchanalian interlude in Las Vegas, there's a wonderful shot of her returning to Germany, her clothes still immaculate but her hair and makeup in meltdown. Aged seventeen, she flies back to America for more. Elvis offers her a little white dog, a red sports car as a graduation gift, and, at long last, his hand in marriage.

;

;In some ways, “Priscilla” is an oddly old-fashioned creation. The passage of time is indicated by the tearing of pages from a calendar, and the prolongation of sex by the sight of trays, bearing food and drink, being left outside a bedroom door. Elvis, we are given to understand, has been saving himself for this pleasure—whether through moral nicety, or from a desire to avoid the crime of intimate relations with a minor, is a question left unresolved. What's clear is that he, no less than Priscilla, is something of a kid; while denying her the comfort of any friends, he is encircled by a rowdy rat pack of pals, who cheer as the King knocks down a house for fun.

;

;To point out that “Priscilla” is superficial, even more so than Coppola's other films, is no derogation, because surfaces are her subject. She examines the skin of the observable world without presuming to seek the flesh beneath, and this latest work is an agglomeration of ;things;—purchases, ornaments, and textures. We see an array of outfits, chosen by Elvis for his wife, each one lovingly accessorized with a handgun. Closeups tell the tale: bare toes, at the start, sinking deep into the nap of a carpet; false eyelashes and china knickknacks; a single pill (the first of many) that Elvis lays on Priscilla's palm, as if it were a Communion wafer; and a mini-sphinx, gilded and ridiculous, that we glimpse as she eventually flees from Graceland. If she stays there any longer, being Mrs. Presley, she, too, will shrink into a thing.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The music we hear, during that final exit, is Dolly Parton singing “I Will Always Love You.” There are no Elvis hits in the film. (Though you may catch a tinkle of “Love Me Tender,” on a music box, as the Presleys hold their baby daughter, Lisa Marie.) This echoing void is well suited to Coppola's purposes; what neater way to present Elvis as a lumpen, insensitive brute than to ignore what made him the greatest joy-bringer on Earth? Slice off his superhuman talents and you haul him down to the level of regular men, as mean and as faithless as the next guy. The late bloom of his Vegas shows, lingered over with relentless panache in Baz Luhrmann's “Elvis” (2022), is distilled here to images of Elvis from behind, onstage—swaying his hips or spreading his cape for the congregation. We need both movies, I would argue: last year's frenzied act of worship and now this irreverent response, all the more potent for being so still and small. “You're the only girl I ever loved, the only girl I want to be with,” Elvis says to Priscilla. He sounds like a cheap song.

;

;What is it, exactly, that Nicolas Cage does? You could call it overacting, especially if you saw “Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans” (2009) or “Mandy” (2018). I prefer to think of Cage's style as ;otheracting;. He approaches the whole racket of dramatic art from an angle untried by his peers, restoring to movie acting the kind of dice-rolling risk that we associate with the theatre. You sense that you could watch him three nights running in the same film, in the same cinema, and find him giving a different performance each time. It's not that he improvises; rather, his characters seem to be improvising their own lives—making themselves up as they go along.

;
;
;

;If “Dream Scenario,” a new film written and directed by Kristoffer Borgli, is one of Cage's most fulfilling ventures, it's because it allows him to trade so richly in the unforeseen. He plays a lecturer named Paul Matthews—has a hero ever borne so numb a name?—who teaches evolutionary biology at a provincial college. He has tenure, spectacles, a shiny pate, a sad beard, a nice house, two daughters, and a long-suffering but loving wife, Janet (Julianne Nicholson). “You score high in assholeness,” she says to him, without rancor. Nobody hates Paul, but nobody really notices him, either. As he gives a class on zebras, noting their ability ;not; to stand out from the herd, we can see his students thinking, Yeah, you should know.

;

;Before long, however, Paul will be hailed as “the most interesting person in the world right now.”为什么？ Because he begins to appear in the dreams of other people—not just people he knows but total strangers, too. This phenomenon is never explained. It's just a splashdown in the collective unconscious, and Paul, understandably, isn't sure how to respond. He's flummoxed at first, then flattered (“I'm special, I guess”), then freaked out; as you can imagine, the emotional to-and-fro is an ideal ride for Cage. Never has that eager grin of his trembled quite so helplessly between anguish and delight.

;
;
;
;
;

;What's particularly welcome about “Dream Scenario” is how undreamy it looks. Borgli switches from reality to reverie with clean, matter-of-fact cuts, affording us precious little opportunity to brace ourselves for the untoward. (Buñuel would raise a glass.) As a bonus, we get a tasty running gag at Paul's expense: once inside the panoply of dreams, he doesn't actually ;do; anything. When one of his students has a nightmare about being stuck on a piano with two alligators slithering toward her, Paul arrives but shows no inclination to help. Someone else's sleeping self is stalked by a gangling figure bathed in blood. Does Paul, strolling by, race to the rescue? Like hell he does. If anything, he's even duller in the kingdom of the fantastical than he is in everyday life.

;

;The trouble is that, for all the comedy and the poignancy of this central concept, the movie requires a plot. It is as if the bowler-hatted residents of Magritte's paintings had to walk out of the frame and go to work. So it is that Paul travels into the city, where he's courted by Trent (Michael Cera), a marketing jerk, who wants to transform Paul into a brand and use him to sell Sprite. One of Trent's employees, Molly (Dylan Gelula), bids Paul bewitch her in her apartment as he recently did in her dream. (Needless to say, the outcome is so humiliating that you'll be left curled up in your seat like a dormouse.) From here on, the story grows oddly vindictive and less appealing. Is Paul being scourged for his venial sins, or for the mortal transgression of yearning to be more than he is?

;

;The easiest—and the least interesting—way to parse this unlikely film is to treat it as an allegory of the Internet. For dream, read meme. “How does it feel to go viral?” Paul is asked, and, once his fame spreads online, it's hardly surprising that he should be dreamed about—he's part of the daily detritus in the public brain—or that his erstwhile contentment should wither and rot. “Dream Scenario” strikes me as more of an Everyman fable, hacking into our obsessions in the way that a movie like “Meet John Doe,” starring Gary Cooper as a drifter caught up in a scam, reflected the anxious mood of 1941. Noble integrity just about carried Cooper through the American Dream. Nicolas Cage, hangdog and half feral, wanders into it, traps a paw, and can't get out. ♦

;In early 2019, I travelled to Afghanistan to investigate the deaths of my mother and sister three decades earlier—a personal search for answers. While seeking out distant relatives in a remote corner of the eastern province of Nangarhar, I met a widow named Mahzala. Sitting before me with shoulders bowed, her small frame cloaked in black, she quietly relayed a story that completely changed the trajectory of my investigation. She told me that her two sons had been killed in a raid several months earlier by masked men who descended on her small home in the middle of the night. She didn't know why they had been targeted, or by whom.

;

;Our chance encounter spurred me to begin investigating the units that had killed her sons. I learnt that the raid on Mahzala's home, along with hundreds of others like it, had been conducted by élite squads of US-backed Afghan Special Forces units, called the Zero units. I found that a disturbing number of the raids appeared to have relied on faulty intelligence or misidentified targets provided by America's intelligence-gathering apparatus.

;
;

;;This film is presented in partnership with ProPublica.;

;
;

;In December of 2022, I published “;The Night Raids;” with ProPublica—the culmination of nearly four years of reporting, more than three hundred and fifty interviews, and visits to the sites of more than thirty raids by the Zero unit across eastern Afghanistan. All told, I investigated and confirmed the deaths of more than four hundred and fifty civilians during the course of my reporting.

;

;Throughout the years, residents in village after village told me how their homes had been swarmed by armed men who descended from helicopters while their families slept. They told me how these soldiers blew off the doors of their homes with explosives, bound the hands of family members, and, in many cases, left a trail of dead behind them—including children. Their families were left behind to grieve with no answers.

;

;I became increasingly preoccupied with the question of what was going through the minds of the soldiers who perpetrated these nightmarish acts. How could they justify their actions, and how could the US justify its support of military units that repeatedly committed such atrocities?

;

;I knew I couldn't finish the story without at least attempting to track down and speak with these soldiers. It took me six months to find two soldiers willing to talk with me. I spent years following their journeys and listening to their accounts of the raids that they participated in and continued to go out on.

;
;
;

;“The Night Doctrine” forces these two disparate experiences—that of the soldier and that of the civilian—into a single short narrative. This film tells the story of one tragic raid, from both perspectives: the soldiers conducting it and the families caught up in it, offering a glimpse into one small part of a much bigger picture—a series of traumas experienced by hundreds of families.

;
;
;

;The animated short is a deeply intimate window into one of the most tragic aspects of ;America's twenty-year war in Afghanistan;.

;

;One of the soldiers I met with, named Baseer, expressed contrition at the results of the raids that he went on in which he targeted his own countrymen. He realized that he had been fighting a failed war against his fellow-Afghans, for a country that he now believes never cared about Afghanistan. He wanted to get out of the Zero units and start a new life free from violence. When ;the US withdrew from Afghanistan;, in August, 2021, he thought this new life might finally be within his grasp.

;

;But, instead, ;America left Baseer behind;. The US had promised to evacuate their Afghan allies, but not all of the Zero-unit members made it out of the country. When we met for the last time, at the same smoky fish restaurant in Kabul where we had first met three years earlier, Baseer told me that the soldiers now live in the shadows. They can't meet one another, and they stay mostly hidden, some moving locations nightly. In 2022, Baseer was detained by the Taliban.

;

;Baseer wants no part of America now. They left without him and let him down.

;

;Now he sells vegetables from a small wooden cart, hoping to save enough to soon make the perilous journey out of Afghanistan by land. Like so many others, he is searching for a new home for himself and his family, far from either Afghanistan or America.

;The new retrospective of the Dutch painter Frans Hals at the National Gallery in London—the first major exhibition of his work since 1989—is a slightly nervous event for the most talented one-trick pony of the seventeenth century. Hals bet everything on portraiture. “Never did he paint Christs, annunciations to shepherds, angels or crucifixions and resurrections; never did he paint voluptuous and bestial naked women,” Vincent van Gogh wrote. “He painted portraits; nothing nothing nothing but that.” His two hundred or so paintings consist of a strict diet of burgomasters, brewers, pipe smokers, regents, street urchins, people holding various things in their hands (donkey's jawbone, stretched pig's bladder), and hundreds of Dutch heads plattered on flat linen collars and millstone ruffs. The question that hangs guillotine-like over the exhibition: Can we love him as much as Rembrandt and Vermeer?

;

;Hals was not the second- or third-best Dutch painter of the seventeenth century; he was the best of the nineteenth. In the eighteen-sixties, the French art critic Théophile Thoré (who famously rescued Vermeer from oblivion) kicked off a revival of Hals, making him a favorite of art collectors and painters—Gustave Courbet and Édouard Manet, Mary Cassatt and James McNeill Whistler, Robert Henri and George Luks. (Luks reportedly said that the only two great painters in history were Hals and himself.) By 1900, the city of Haarlem had installed a statue of Hals in a public park. Even as he fell behind Rembrandt and Vermeer in the twentieth century, his paintings would retain a sheen of newness. According to the painter Lucian Freud, Hals was “fated always to look modern.”

;

;His genius boils down to a contradiction: loose, unblended smears of paint that create the flesh-and-blood likeness of a human being. The late works of Titian, Velázquez, and Rembrandt would all head in this direction with their “rough” manner, but Hals achieved a kind of scary immediacy that seemed almost foreign to the medium—a photographer suddenly among painters. One of his satisfied customers, the scholar Theodorus Schrevelius, said that Hals's portraits seemed “to breathe and to live.” His style was so distinct that he rarely even signed his paintings. There's a sort of taunting element to them, with their passages of waxy smoothness that suddenly combust into vibrating little sparks. Your eye can never really settle on the picture; it's constantly being stirred and needled by the brushwork.

;

;What we know about Hals with certainty—and it's not much—is that he was born in Antwerp between 1582 and 1584, and spent most of his eighty-plus years in Haarlem, about eleven miles from Amsterdam, swatting away various kinds of debt. (A nursemaid, tavern owner, tradesman, and baker all took him to court.) He married twice and fathered at least fourteen children, five of whom he buried, and two of whom he sent to workhouses—a daughter for being promiscuous, a son for being mentally disabled. He died, penniless, in the summer of 1666.

;

;You wouldn't expect this man to be a famous painter of warm cheer and tavern jollity, whose trademark expressions were smiling and laughter. Nor would you expect him to be paying off his debt with furniture when the Dutch economy was booming. Just before Hals was born, the Dutch Republic had broken away from Spain and declared its independence. A low-lying, semiliquid territory (what one Englishman described as “the buttock of the world”) was being dried out by windmills and converted into the center of a global trade empire. Artists like Hals and Rembrandt didn't have a Philip IV of Spain or a Cardinal Barberini in Rome—there was no longer a royal family, and Catholicism was only begrudgingly tolerated, so court and church commissions were minimal—but they could secure private commissions from aldermen, textile magnates, the remnants of noble families, or preachers, doctors, and an ascendant middle class. The Dutch were a God-chosen people, and they were hungry for images of themselves.

;;;;

;The National Gallery exhibition includes fifty paintings and is a more streamlined version of the 1989 retrospective. When we first meet Hals, he's around thirty years old and a ;meester schilder; (master painter) in the local art guild. There are no juvenilia or early false starts; no one even knows what he was doing for the first part of his life, though one source tells us that he was “lusty” as a youth. His early portrait of Pieter Cornelisz van der Mersch (1616), a satirist from Leiden, shows Hals already at full tilt, bearing a style that's not too far-flung from where he would land fifty years later. Van der Mersch has a herring pinched in his right hand and a bundle of straw in the other. The gesture is a riff on a Dutch proverb that means something like “to take the piss out of someone.” As will become his custom, Hals paints the portrait like he's short on time. The linen cuff on van der Mersch's right hand is done in four touches, max. Even when you're standing ten feet back from the canvas, you can peel off individual brushstrokes with your eyes. They're just floating there, like little spears of light.

;
;
;

;The two showstoppers of the exhibition appear in the second room, grouped under the elusive theme of “Portraiture into Art.” The first is “The Laughing Cavalier” (1624), Hals's most famous painting, though it's not a particularly Halsian one. Sure, the sitter has a Renaissance elbow—the arms-akimbo pose Hals used to give his portraits more depth and swagger—but the smooth density of the man's face is much more van Dyck-ish. The painting is on loan from the nearby Wallace Collection, where it typically hangs on sumptuous red wallpaper and gets a lot of admiring attention. Here, it almost slumps into the gallery of faces.

;

;The real coup of the exhibition is Hals's masterpiece “Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard” (circa 1627), which has left Haarlem for the first time since it was painted nearly four hundred years ago. Between 1616 and 1664, Hals was commissioned to paint nine major group portraits—six of militiamen and three of regents. To see what he did for group portraiture as a genre, compare his 1627 painting with Cornelis van Haarlem's portrait of the same guard, from 1599. In the van Haarlem, the whole scene is overcrowded and stiff. Every officer's mouth is zipped shut, and all of the faces look vaguely milky and homogenous. With Hals, you're turning up to a live banquet. The lieutenant Frederik Coning has a lemon in his fist and is mid-squeeze over a tray of plump oysters. (It's moments like these that Hals is famous for.) The star of the painting is the guard's captain, Michiel de Wael, who wears a yellow jerkin with an icy-blue sash in the foreground. His loose-jawed, watery facial expression, the critic John Berger once noted, had never been captured before in paint: “We watch Captain de Wael as the sober always watch a man getting tipsy—coldly and very aware of being an outsider. It is like watching a departure for a journey we haven't the means to make.”

;

;In the sixteen-twenties and thirties, Hals came into his own as a so-called genre painter, moving beyond strict portraiture. In a part of the exhibition devoted to his “Invented Characters,” we meet the staples of Halsania: the merry drinkers, the boys playing lutes, the fisher children, the deranged woman with an owl on her shoulder. These were cheaper paintings that could be sold via auction or lottery and hang in family homes, butcher shops, or brothels. Hals didn't have to satisfy the vanity of a newly married couple or the scion of a wealthy brewer clan. His brushwork could fully unwind, and his worst (or best) painterly habits found their match in comic characters like “Pekelharing” (1625), whose face appears to be sliding off itself like a warm cheese. Is he drunk, or are we?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;By the sixteen-forties, portraits in the Dutch Republic had taken a Flemish turn: slender faces and fingers, a “smooth” manner of painting, a fetish for shiny fabric. Hals dutifully paints the fashions of the moment but keeps doing it in his own freewheeling way. In his portrait of the perfectly arrogant Jasper Schade, a Dutch politician, the brushwork on the face is tightly thatched and then, as if Hals has suddenly swallowed a caffeine pill, a whole taffeta sleeve bursts into a lightning field. The paintings gradually get looser, darker. (Van Gogh once claimed that Hals had twenty-seven different blacks.) When we reach his last piece in the exhibition, “Regents of the Old Men's Alms House” (1664), Hals has gone full Manet. He's in his eighties and appears to be freed from whatever demands his sitters might have. One of the almshouse regents looks like a melted puppet. Another could be easily mistaken for a corpse.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Until Thoré revived Hals in the nineteenth century, he was known less for his painting than for his drinking. All of the relevant tidbits—that he couldn't keep out of the taverns, that he once kissed van Dyck, that his apprentices tucked him into bed at night—come from a largely discredited 1718 account by Arnold Houbraken. In the exhibition catalogue, the art historian Jaap van der Veen makes the enticing rear-guard choice to revive part of Houbraken's account. Who's to say that Hals did not “fill himself to the gills each evening”? He was not especially productive, he likely shirked administrative duties in his local art guild, and his finances were chronically mismanaged. Maybe it was a thirst for Rhenish wine or ale. Maybe Hals was just lazy.

;

;This exhibition follows a ;blockbuster Vermeer show; at the Rijksmuseum, which sold over half a million tickets, and a landmark Rembrandt retrospective in 2019, which turned into a “year of Rembrandt” celebration. A run-of-the-mill Hals exhibition feels vaguely doomed by comparison, as though we're resigned to giving him the bronze medal of the Dutch Golden Age. Vermeer's paintings have inspired an opera, a rockabilly song, and a feature film with Scarlett Johansson (“Girl with a Pearl Earring”); Rembrandt has a town in Iowa named after him, as well as a toothpaste. The best argument you could make for Hals is that he excelled at making more with less. How much feeling could be squeezed into a single brushstroke? How much range into a single genre (portraiture)? How much personality into a single color (black)? A single pose (the Renaissance elbow)? A single expression (laughter)?

;

;Hals was a painter of fundamentally modest means with a deep intuition for his medium. If he were alive today, one imagines that he'd feel rather confused about the fuss over his work. His one surviving self-portrait is from a 1639 painting of the St George Civic Guard, still in Haarlem, where you can see Hals in the upper left-hand corner, peeping out between two sets of shoulders. He looks almost surprised to have made it into his own picture. After all, wasn't he only a portraitist? It was a profession, not a calling. His job was to disappear into the paint. ♦

;In a ;year; of ;impressive; ;débuts;, the first feature by the writer and director Raven Jackson, “All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt,” which opens Friday, is the best so far.这是一部经过全面想象和实现的电影，它的每一个元素都充满了原创性、灵感和美感。电影的每个方面都预示着真正的电影感：故事和对话；选角和表演；对衣服、家具和地点的眼睛；图像的构图、对光线的关注以及大胆的剪辑；声音设计和乐谱跟踪动作的精确度。 The result is a film that feels like a world come alive—or, rather, two worlds, Jackson's inner one and the outer one of shared experience.

;

;“All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt” is a multigenerational saga, spanning half a century in the life of its protagonist, Mackenzie (nicknamed Mack), a Black woman who grows up in rural Mississippi in the nineteen-sixties and seventies. （她由四位不同的女演员在不同的年龄扮演。）然而，这部电影最独特和最有力的成就是在时间领域。如果杰克逊备用剧本中的事件以传统的节奏和传统的舞台拍摄，那么这部电影将是一部较长的短片，可能有三十或四十分钟。如果她拍摄了这个影响广泛的故事中暗示或暗示的全部事件，那么这部电影将持续四个小时或成为一部迷你剧。 As it is, Jackson has shot a film that, despite its unexceptional ninety-seven-minute duration, exhibits a daring conception of cinematic time.

;

;Mack grows up in a loving household with her father, Isaiah (Chris Chalk), her mother, Evelyn (Sheila Atim), and her sister, Josie (Jayah Henry).小时候（由凯莉·妮可·约翰逊饰演），麦克骑着自行车，与她的朋友们在树林、空地和游泳池里进行认真有趣的冒险。十几岁的时候，她与另一个名叫伍德（当时由普雷斯顿·麦克道威尔饰演）的青少年展开了一段轻浮的恋情。但麦克的母亲去世了，以赛亚将孩子们送去与祖母贝蒂（詹妮·汉普顿饰）住在一起，将麦克从伍德身边撬开。 The separation weighs heavily on her, throughout the course of her life, even as she lives as fully as possible in her new surroundings, eventually working and advancing, marrying, and having a child.

;

;The stories of Mack's life are told not in chronological order but as a temporal mosaic.这部电影的时间框架交织在一起，在几年和几十年之间来回跳跃。这种技巧并不是一种主要现在时的闪回。相反，有一种感觉，在记忆中，甚至在一个家庭、一个地区和一个社区的集体生活中，过去、现在和未来通过教义和遗产、预言和预感结合在一起。 Scenes bringing Mack and Josie together with their grandmother have a special air of transcending time's arrow by connection with the spiritual realm.

;

;The action displays a rare convergence of a seemingly literary conception with a specificity of observation that suggests documentary.杰克逊与电影摄影师乔莫·弗雷 (Jomo Fray) 合作，将手势和戏剧结合起来，创造出大胆而细致的片段，而在大多数电影中，这些片段只会在一两个平淡的说明性镜头中出现。伊芙琳的葬礼结束后，离开家乡的旅程与女孩们的双手密不可分，小卡车放在以赛亚驾驶的皮卡车的蓝色凹槽底板上。但这幅图像嵌入了一幅精致的、交响乐般的体验拼贴画中，从他们身后道路上的树叶景色，到透过出租车后窗看到的以赛亚驾驶的景象，再到女孩们的发型和衣服。这个蒙太奇，就像整部电影中的许多蒙太奇一样，在一段非常持续的时间跨度上发展出一个令人心碎的时刻；这些结构通过美学的方式唤起了记忆本身的力量。 The movie opens with young Mack getting a waterfront lesson in fishing from her father, and it, too, involves an array of visuals: the handling of the fish, the manipulation of a reel and a line, the use of a basket, and the lesson that follows, from Evelyn, in the family kitchen, in cleaning and preparing the catch for cooking—a shimmery sensory rapture, in which the gestures of hands, the postures of bodies, tones of voice, and deep moods imbue minor incidents with an aura of epic grandeur.

;
;
;

;In moments of overtly great dramatic import, Jackson's inspiration rises to the occasion, as in the scene of Mack's wedding, where, during the singing of a spiritual, the parishioners are shown not singing along but in portraits, one by one, in extreme closeup, in a mode that joins shared devotional fervor with private contemplative stillness. Jackson and Fray cap the scene with a camera move of quiet bravura, roving past the couple to look out one window and then another, as if connecting the events inside the church with the life of the community, with the world at large.

;

;Similarly, the movie's dialogue is spare but not scant;杰克逊的台词具有宝石般的力量和密度，而她的演员则以一种传达其中蕴含的体验的方式来表达它们。 “我看着我的爸爸在差点杀了我之后向我走来，但我想我看到了我需要看到的东西，”伍德谈到他父亲艰苦的游泳课时说道。麦克对水的描述包含了一种经久不衰的形而上学：“它不会结束或开始，它只是改变形式，”她说。 “有一天，所有这些水滴可能会成为一条河流，可能会成为雪，也可能会在你身上。”言语、人物的动作或目光都没有不自然地放慢；他们只是被给予适当的空间和重量。强调和停顿、犹豫和温柔似乎反映了深思熟虑的生活节奏。一次又一次，许多电影只是传达信息，而杰克逊的电影则传达质感。 And when a scene shows Mack and Wood meeting again as adults (played by Charleen McClure and Reginald Helms, Jr.), Jackson pulls thoroughly familiar gestures of affection out of the realm of cliché, investing them with astonishment and wonder.

;

;With most films, the avoidance of spoilers is a courtesy;对于“所有土路的盐味”来说，这几乎是道德和审美上的必然。我只想说，基本情节涉及一系列事件，我发现这些事件在多维度上令人惊叹——从构思它的电影制片人和生活在其中的角色的角度来想象是非常了不起的。这部电影我已经看了三遍，虽然只有一次让我感到惊讶，但每次我都屏住呼吸。这在很大程度上与一个巨大的六分钟序列有关——它的方式平静而内敛，而其紧张而安静的表达方式却充满爆炸性——这是近年来伟大的电影选集之一。 I've often ;discussed; ;melodrama; as a crucial cinematic form, for its ability to endow ordinary lives with the furies of tragedy. 《土路都是盐的味道》是近年来最优秀的情节剧之一，不仅因为它以如此深情的关怀看待平凡的生活，而且因为它的悲剧感是如此崇高和崇高。 ♦

;Nine days ago, the idea that an obscure 2020 election denier from Shreveport, Louisiana, with less than five thousand dollars in his household's bank accounts, a literalist's belief in the presence of dinosaurs on Noah's Ark, and a dubious past as an advocate of “conversion” therapy for gay teens could single-handedly shape the fate of tens of billions of dollars in US military assistance to key allies at war was even more preposterous than the notion that America might soon reëlect its four-times-indicted former President.

;

;But these are not normal times in our politics.作为新任共和党众议院议长，迈克·约翰逊现在对哪些法案在国会进行投票拥有巨大的权力，他决定将他任期内的第一场重大斗争打造成与白宫和民主党控制的参议院的争议。向以色列和乌克兰提供紧急援助。与此同时，在参议院，来自阿拉巴马州的第一任共和党议员汤米·图伯维尔(Tommy Tuberville)因担任奥本大学橄榄球队主教练而闻名，他在过去九个月里发起了一场单人运动，阻止了数百名军事晋升。随着中东爆发新的战争以及五角大楼关键职位令人尴尬的空缺威胁到美国的战备状态，他的共和党同事本周终于真正反击，周三晚上的大部分时间都在参议院对图伯维尔大喊大叫。 “我不尊重那些不遵守诺言的人，”来自爱荷华州的参议员乔尼·恩斯特 (Joni Ernst) 气呼呼地说道。阿拉斯加的丹·沙利文抱怨图伯维尔的“国家安全自杀任务”。他补充说：“习近平很喜欢这个。普京亦是如此。 How dumb can we be, man?”

;

;The answer, of course, is very dumb.即使遭到共和党同僚的严厉批评，图伯维尔仍拒绝放松封锁。而且，在众议院，约翰逊坚定地坚持一项奇怪的要求——这是他担任议长期间的第一个实质性要求——即用同等金额的国税局削减来抵消向以色列提供的 140 亿美元战时援助。 Even a ruling from the Congressional Budget Office that the cuts would actually ;cost; the Treasury ;nearly twenty-seven billion dollars; by reducing the amount in taxes that a budget-constrained IRS could collect did not deter Johnson.预计参议院不会批准这一方案，白宫威胁称，如果众议院削减国税局的版本送到总统办公桌上，白宫将否决该法案。 Nonetheless, Johnson plunged ahead.

;

;While picking this fight over urgent—and historically bipartisan—money for Israel, Johnson also refused to include in the emergency spending bill sixty billion dollars in additional Ukraine aid that President Biden has requested.结果是，还没有人真正知道以色列或乌克兰的钱在哪里。 Maybe the Senate, where both parties' leaders and a bipartisan majority support the broader funding approach, will find a way around the new Speaker, who now claims privately that he ;isn't really as opposed to helping Ukraine; as his record of voting against previous assistance suggests.也许不会。这就是美国外交政策制定的现状。 The week's events on Capitol Hill ought to remind us that not all national-security threats are overseas.

;

;I've been watching this all play out from Berlin, where nervous allies are asking once again what the volatile state of American politics means for the rest of the world. Few countries have more at stake in the upcoming US Presidential election than ;Germany, a favorite target of former President Donald Trump; during his four years in office.我在这里进行的对话不可避免地包括特朗普是否真的能够克服他的四项刑事起诉的问题，以及他在2020年选举中击败拜登的谎言的耻辱。 “距离这里一天车程的地方正在发生一场大规模的陆地战争，我认为大多数德国人更关注美国民主的命运，”前美国外交官、柏林美国学院院长丹尼尔·本杰明（Daniel Benjamin）接待了我。对于美国政治的讨论，说。 “They're scarred [by Trump], and they worry a lot about it.”

;
;
;

;The current American President is arguably much more popular here than he is in the United States—a recent ;Pew poll found that sixty-seven per cent; of Germans trust Biden to do the right thing in international affairs, versus ten per cent of Germans who thought Trump would do so in the final year of his Presidency. (Biden's current ;approval rating at home;, meanwhile, stands at an average of fifty-four-per-cent disapproval and just thirty-nine-and-a-half-per-cent approval—near the nadir he hit in the summer of 2022.) This is not just about lefty Europeans turning up their noses at a crude right-wing American politician.拜登更喜欢与盟友合作，而不是特朗普抨击他们；他对乌克兰的大力支持与特朗普对乌克兰领导人的勒索形成鲜明对比； and his decades of support for ;NATO; at a time when ;NATO; is facing the biggest threat to European security since the end of the Cold War are all real, specific differences. Trump, in contrast, has threatened to pull out of ;NATO; altogether—John Bolton, his former national-security adviser, has ;said he is likely to do so if given a second term;—and just the other day ;he bragged to an audience; in Sioux City, Iowa, that he had threatened not to defend other ;NATO; countries, even in response to a Russian military assault. “这是否意味着，如果俄罗斯攻击我的国家，你将不会在那里？” Trump quoted a fellow ;NATO; leader asking him. “没错，”特朗普在观众欢呼声中说道。 “我不会保护你。”别介意美国受联盟条款的约束，必须向其他成员国提供援助。 Trump does not consider himself obliged to follow either treaties or long-standing bipartisan traditions of national security—and his views are increasingly shared by other Republicans for whom talking tough on Russia was, until the Trump era, an article of bedrock conviction.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Perhaps the most pressing fear one hears in Europe is about aid for Ukraine.无论多么难以想象，考虑到西方对基辅防御做出的巨大承诺，华盛顿的国会功能失调可能意味着美国的援助在乌克兰当前的反攻结束之前就枯竭了。民意调查显示，美国各政治派别对继续支持乌克兰的热情正在减弱，尤其是但不仅限于共和党人； ;in a recent Gallup poll;, sixty-two per cent of Republicans and forty-four per cent of independents said the US was doing too much to help Ukraine, an increase of ten points since June.

;

;From the start of the war, Biden has worked arm in arm on Ukraine with Chancellor Olaf Scholz. Germany, as part of its so-called ;Zeitenwende;, a painful and not fully complete pivot in its foreign policy since Russia's invasion, is now committed to spend more than two per cent of its GDP on defense—an increase that Trump loudly demanded but never could achieve. It has also ;broken its dependence on Russian energy;, a radical shift from before the war, when Germany imported around half of its gas and more than a third of its oil from Russia and was set to open the now cancelled Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline.

;

;But its level of military assistance is only a small subset of the large sums that Washington has spent supplying Kyiv. American aid is, for now, irreplaceable on the battlefield.

;

;And yet the more profound worry—here in Berlin, and elsewhere in the West—goes far deeper than how much is spent in sending long-range missiles to Ukraine or on helping Israel eradicate Hamas.这是关于美国重新选举一位不遵守西方联盟基本原则或美国宪法基本原则的总统的真正可能性。 In “;The Divider;,” the recent book that I wrote with my husband, we recounted how John Kelly, the former Marine general and Trump's chief of staff, was shocked by Trump's admiration for the Nazi generals who prosecuted the Second World War. “你们这些该死的将军，为什么不能像德国将军那样呢？”特朗普曾一度告诉凯利。 Recounting this story to an audience in Berlin elicited only stunned silence.

;

;Germans don't get a vote in the upcoming US Presidential election, but, as much as anywhere in the world, they get what is on the line. ♦
